MAIN ESTIMATES 1961 (Contd.)


    Head 47 -

    Question again proposed.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think all yesterday the Opposition was giving every possible reason why they boycotted the National Day and National Loyalty Week rallies, except the right one. They know what the real reason was, and I think they know that I know what the real reason was. But unless it is their desire to prolong the debate on the subject, I will just confine myself to clarifying one or two points raised yesterday.

    One accusation was that the National Day rally was a P.A.P. show. Sir, if by that is meant that the P.A.P. as a Party was very prominent in the celebrations, let me just give an indication of some of the items that were scheduled to take place during National Day. First, I think we started off with the National Day rally which did not take place, and the Member for the Southern Islands flattered the Government by blaming it for not arranging the weather. We shall try to do better next time. But that was the only occasion on which P.A.P. members, as members

Column: 487

of a political Party, would have participated. And out of the 20,000 people who would have participated in the rally, something like 3,500 would have been P.A.P. members. Therefore, by no stretch of the imagination could that rally be described as a P.A.P. show. That was followed immediately by the Prime Minister's reception to political, civic, trade union and cultural representatives. Surely, Sir, that could not be described as a P.A.P. show. Then there was the National Economic Development Fair sponsored by the Government, the Trades Union Congress, and the Chambers of Commerce. Was that a P.A.P. show? Then there were three open-air concerts. At none of these was the P.A.P. represented, nor did the P.A.P. as a political Party take an active part. Then there was an Art exhibition; again organised not by the P.A.P. but by local artists. Then there was a fun-fair at the Raffles Institution, organised by the T.U.C. and not by the P.A.P. There were a number of sports events, again organised by sports organisations. There was a mass tatoo organised by schools. So, Sir, this allegation that the National Day celebrations were a P.A.P. show has no shred of truth to it. As I have said, the only occasion was when during National Loyalty Week P.A.P. members participated in the mass rally, there were something like 30 to 40 different groups.

    The other contention by the Member for the Southern Islands was that the Opposition was not consulted. What he really meant was not that the Opposition was not consulted but that something like 40 representatives who were there did not take the advice of representatives of the S.P.A. and U.M.N.O. Their advice was that no political Party should display flags or banners. That was the point of view put forward, and everyone else except the representatives of these two political Parties saw no objection. The S.P.A., U.M.N.O. representatives, walked out of the meeting. In fact, we did not know that they walked out of the meeting. All we saw were three people quietly walking out, and then on the following day there was

Column: 488

a news report claiming that the members concerned had staged a walkout. We were not interested in making a political issue out of National Day celebrations. So, just as on the first occasion during National Loyalty Week when they themselves announced in the newspapers that they had staged a boycott, all that the Government did was to express regret that they were not able to participate, and we would not make an issue out of it. On the second occasion - that was last year - they issued a statement to the Press saying that this was a P.A.P. show; the Minister was unreasonable; they were not consulted; they were presented with a set schedule, and they were asked to accept or not to accept it. That is not quite true, because the discussion at the first meeting - there were about 40 other organisations there - started from April and went on till the end of May. Many suggestions were put forward by the other organisations. Some were accepted by the Government, and some were scrapped. But the S.P.A. representatives and the U.M.N.O. representatives decided to pull out and to make an issue out of the whole thing. Again we refused to be drawn into making an issue out of it. All that we did was to have the Parliamentary Secretary issue a statement, again expressing regret that the two political Parties could not participate in these celebrations.

    Sir, the main contention is not that political Parties should not participate in National Day celebrations - that they concede - but what they say is that if political Parties participate, they should conceal their identity. They say you must not display a flag or a banner. In fact, yesterday the Member for Farrer Park said that if a political Party displayed its flag or banner, the Head of State would be put in the invidious position of having to salute a Party flag. Sir, I am quite sure the Member for Farrer Park put that forward purely as an argument. The Yang di-Pertuan Negara did not salute the P.A.P. flag any more than he saluted the flags that were carried by the Chinese Chamber of Commerce, the

Column: 489

Singapore Dance Hostesses Association and the Singapore Trishaw Riders Association. He did salute them, but he was not saluting their flags! He was acknowledging the respect that was being accorded to him as the Head of State on that day by various sections of the population. So the Opposition concede, in fact, that every other organisation can display their flag, can show their identity. But for some obscure reason, they say that if political Parties display their identities, they are going to create an impression among the people that they are putting forward, on the day of national unity, symbols which emphasise differences. If that is so, Sir, the others also emphasised differences - the Chambers of Commerce showed there were three Chambers of Commerce in this country. The schools went one by one, showing the different schools - Malay schools, Chinese schools, English schools. Could we not apply the same argument and say that on that day the schools which used to be under the care of the Member for Tanglin should have got mixed up with Chung Cheng High School or some other school?

2.45 p.m.

    What, I think, they really object to is not that the political Parties should not display symbols. We are not ashamed, Sir, of our Party symbol, or of the hundreds of thousands of people who have helped the Party to realise its ideals and who are responsible for our being here. We are not, ashamed of all these people. Therefore, we were not going to insult them on that day by saying, "You can participate in this rally only on condition that you disguise yourself as sheep or goats." We said, "No. You are P.A.P. members and you should be proud of the fact." I think what the Opposition really wanted was to have an anonymous body of political organisations so that P.A.P. members might be mistaken for S.P.A., and U.M.N.O. members, which is not fair to the P.A.P. members. And U.M.N.O. and S.P.A. members might be mistaken for P.A.P. members, which again, I say, is not fair

Column: 490

to their supporters who obviously believe in the S.P.A. and U.M.N.O. Therefore, Sir, all these arguments do not count for anything. The real reason, as I have said, is that all they wanted was one anonymous group of political parties so that they could probably claim that there were fewer P.A.P. members than there really were; and, secondly, I think, all the protests may be part of the general strategy of the Opposition parties to show that things are getting from bad to worse and that the Government has achieved nothing. A National Day celebration as everybody acknowledges has had some impact, and to that extent, they have been trying to pour cold water on an occasion which at least we have hoped would be free of political controversy and political party squabbles. But, unfortunately, they have seen fit to bring that occasion into disrepute by alleging, quite falsely, that it is a P.A.P. show, that it is organised by P.A.P. members, and that it is an occasion to put forward P.A.P propaganda. As I have said, out of all the celebrations, the only occasion when the P.A.P. got some prominence was when it marched as one of the 20,000 people who marched past the Head of State.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, the Minister for Culture has just explained at great length the details concerning the National Day celebrations in Singapore. We do not question the detailed aspect of the celebrations. What we are questioning here is the principle or the manner in which the Government had organised such a National Day celebration. We are of the opinion that the organisation did not aim at the ideals which were intended originally. If we were to comment item by item on the programme during the National Day celebrations, it would take us a long time to do it. But I would like to quote an instance where the people in the celebrations were forced to participate. They did not participate of their own free will but because of forced circumstances.

Column: 491

They had no alternative but to participate, because of their position, their livelihood, and their circumstances. Pressure was put upon them by the Government, and they were thus obliged to take part in the celebrations.

    Mr Speaker, for instance, the Chambers of Commerce. National Day could be considered to be a day of pride for the State of Singapore. As regards the response given by the businessmen, we observed that only a few of the commercial buildings put up bunting in the real sense of the word. We saw the bunting put up by the Government. It costs $42,000, and was spoilt by the rain on that day. If on that day we were able to get a response from every section of the community and each and every citizen did his bit to make the celebrations a success, it was because they were forced to participate; there was no expression of sincerity in them.

    There is also another point. This concerns the residents of the Southern Islands who were requested to participate in the sea sports during the National Day celebrations. They were forced to participate in the kolek race, and they were housed at the Telok Ayer basin. They were given accommodation and food and so on. These islanders were dissatisfied with the facilities accorded to them, because, apart from the fact that they had to leave their homes for two or three days - at least they had to leave their kampongs for two days - they had to row their koleks to Singapore and return empty-handed. Normally, if they were required to participate in an important event on an auspicious occasion such as this, they would be given allowances, and transport facilities would be provided for them to arrive at Singapore, and they would not be asked to row their own boats from the islands to Singapore. This was a mistake which I could quote on how the organisers organised according to their whims, without caring to hear the views of the other sections.

    The meetings organised to run the National Day celebrations were ready-made, and the committee members were

Column: 492

given all the resolutions to adopt, and there was no chance for them to put up their views. What we submit is that all sections should organise such a celebration so that we could really participate in it, as was organised by the previous Government. That is, it should be by way of forming a sub-committee comprising representatives from all political Parties in Singapore, and not like the organisation conducted or run by the Government.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Inche Yaacob Bin Mohamed)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I would like to draw the attention of the Member for the Southern Islands to the residents of the Southern Islands who participated in the National Day celebrations. As far as I know, the islanders were provided with more than what they normally received. It is a fact that the people of the Southern Islands had participated in the kolek race, for instance, like the ones held at Ayer Gumuroh and Siglap. They voluntarily came without their having to be provided with food and so on. It has become a custom to them. Not only in Singapore but also, to the best of my knowledge, quite recently when celebrating the birthday of the Sultan of Johore, the residents of the Southern Islands left their homes for a week or so and went to take part in the kolek race. However, in last year's National Day celebrations, we invited them to take part in the kolek race and they willingly agreed to participate. We gave them lodgings, accommodation, apart from the prizes awarded to the winners. I am quite sure that the islanders were not forced to take part. On the contrary, they gave of their best during the National Day celebrations, a thing which has become part and parcel of their everyday lives. For instance, during the New Year's kolek race, we see the islanders taking part. I can say that I am very close with the islanders there, and so far I have not received any complaints from them about their participation in last year's National Day celebrations.

Column: 493



    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I am obliged to seek clarification on this subject from the Minister for Culture. Because U.M.N.O. has been repeatedly mentioned, I would like to stress U.M.N.O.'s attitude. We agreed, in principle, to celebrate National Day, but what we could not accept were the things that were done and which had been explained by the Member for the Southern Islands and to which objection was taken. Mr Speaker, I am one of the representatives from U.M.N.O. We received an invitation from the Ministry of Culture. It is imperative that I receive further clarification, because I know that when we were invited by the Ministry of Culture, we replied and accepted the invitation.

3.00 p.m.

    However, we were present at the meeting. But, again I shall require a further explanation from the Minister for Culture, because it appears that at that particular meeting which was fixed by the Ministry of Culture, no mention whatsoever was made in the agenda regarding the matters to be raised for further discussion and reconsideration by our side. But since the Minister for Culture has accused us of this and that, I would like to ask him if that is the manner in which a meeting, especially of political parties, should be conducted. I feel that that is nothing short of steamrollering the issue. If everything is to be forced on us, U.M.N.O., so that we will have no opportunity to submit our views, then I think no useful purpose can be served by throwing allegations at us.

    There is another point, Mr Speaker, which I would like to explain to this House. I wish to congratulate and pay my tribute to the Prime Minister of this State. I knew how difficult it was when we tried to draw up a national flag. Meeting after meeting was held, but he was prepared to reconsider and accept our views and findings. Why is it that the Minister for Culture could not adopt the same attitude? I therefore require an explanation from the Minister.

Column: 494



    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, we, the Opposition Parties on this side of the House, still believe that political parties as such should not participate in National Day celebrations. My suggestion yesterday evening was merely a concession to the P.A.P. Government, that if they felt it was vital that political parties should participate, then we would concede the point to them; but we asked them to concede a point to us, that the flags be dispensed with. So far as we are concerned, Mr Speaker, Sir, this occasion is as important as the national flag.

    The Member for Kampong Kembangan has said what, in fact, did take place when the State was considering the question of a national flag. On that occasion, Mr Speaker, the political parties concerned were invited. There was a vast difference between the nature of the first flag which was presented at that meeting and the flag that we have today as the flag of the State of Singapore. A big difference, which on the first occasion seemed to us to be unbridgeable. But after three or four days of coming and going, likely breakdowns, almost certain breakdowns, we eventually got a solution. The reason, Mr Speaker, was that both sides wanted a solution; and thank God, a solution was found. Because if the Government had gone ahead as they had originally intended, we would not have had a national flag and the flag would have become a political issue. If the Government had not been able to seek the agreement of the political parties on this side, Mr Speaker, Sir, our intention was to make this a political issue in the forthcoming elections. But I am sure the Government is glad, and we also are glad, that that is not a political issue today. All of us are 100 per cent behind the flag. It is our flag. It is not the Government's flag, the P.A.P.'s flag the U.M.N.O.'s flag, or the S.P.A.'s flag, but the people of Singapore's flag. If that is the correct attitude to adopt on a national matter such as this, why is the Minister for Culture being so adamant about the National Day celebration? We think the National Day celebration is just as important as the

Column: 495

national flag. They go hand in hand, and yet the Minister for Culture does not want to move an inch. Why?

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 47 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 21.

    Sub-head 21 is "Contribution to the Maintenance of Caldecott Hill Estate". Mr Speaker, Sir, I notice that the figure does not appear in the 1960 Estimates. It appears to be a new item of expenditure which is being incurred by the Government. Could we have an explanation why this was found to be necessary?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Yes, Sir. Caldecott Hill Estate is a private residential estate belonging to the Estate of the late Mr Mistri. Radio Singapore is sited on land in this estate purchased from the Estate of Mr Mistri. By virtue of an indenture of conveyance dated 25th June, 1960, the Government is liable to contribute to the maintenance of the estate roads, site cables and septic tank. There was no provision in the 1960 Estimates, because there was then some discussion as to whether the indenture of conveyance might not be abrogated. However, agreement was reached with the Trustees of the Estate that the Government pays one-third contribution towards the maintenance of the estate. $808,000 is the estimated amount based on what it has cost in the past The total expenditure from 1st January, 1953, to 30th September, 1959, was about $53,000. So the average for one year is about $8,000.

    Mr Rajah: In view of that explanation, Sir, may I be given leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    Sir, the vote asked for is just a token vote of $10. We would, therefore, like the Minister to give us more details of what this service means and what the total cost would be.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, first, I must apologise for a printing mistake. It should read "medium" and not "short wave" service. Suara Singapura is a new medium wave service. It is intended that it should be more national in character, in the sense that all announcements will be in the national language, though the programme content will be from the four cultural streams. In fact, practically all the non-Malay announcers and programme staff of Radio Singapore have already undergone a course in simple Malay announcements. It is hoped that the service would come into operation sometime in the middle of 1961. Although the planning has already gone ahead, it is not yet known for certain what would be the exact amount, and therefore a token vote of $10 has been entered for 1961.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, would the Minister give us just an indication of what the amount would be? Is it $100,000, $10,000 or $200,000? We just want a rough indication.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, I am not quite sure, because all we know is that we will be getting back the three short-wave transmitters from the Federation at the end of this year. But I am afraid I have no indication from my staff as to exactly how much it would cost. But what it will amount to is that we will have to buy a new medium-wave transmitter and, if I understand correctly, it costs something like $70,000 or $80,000. But I am not sure.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, leaving aside the merits of instituting such a service, I am sure if the Minister thinks it is good for Singapore, we will accept that. But I think, from the financial point of view, the House must be told what he expects to be the capital expenditure on this and what he thinks are going to be the

Column: 497

annually recurrent charges. Merely putting down a sum there as capital cost is not sufficient. I think the Minister for Finance will support me in this: that we must also know what the annually recurrent charges are going to be. Sometimes in approving a vote, the more important things to consider are the annually recurrent charges rather than the capital expenditure.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, among the many virtues of my colleague, the Minister for Culture, a grasp of financial matters is not outstanding. I, however, feel that the Member for Farrer Park is trying to take advantage of this particular weakness of my colleague and that he was really talking with his tongue in his cheek. The thing is this: if indeed we had all the plans worked out, they would then have been entered there in complete detail. But, of course, it is because it takes some time to work out the details of the staffing, programme activities and so forth, that we have just entered a token vote. No doubt in course of time, this Assembly will be fully informed of what it is proposed to do with this section.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, may I have the assurance of the Hon. the Minister for Finance that before expenditure is in fact incurred, the Assembly will be consulted?

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Even if we are not consulted, he will spend it!

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I said the Assembly would be informed, Sir.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, the point remains that before the Assembly passes this $10 token vote, it is imperative that it knows what the total capital expenditure is going to be and what the annually recurrent charges are likely to be. But if the Minister feels that he is not in a position to give these estimates at the moment, I think, in fairness to the Assembly, he should concede the point that before these expenditures are incurred, the Assembly will be consulted.

3.15 p.m.

    We do not know unless the details are given as to whether the project is a laudable one or not. We are not in a position even to dispute it in principle, unless we really know what it intends to do, whom it intends to reach, and what the programmes are likely to be; whether it is going to be cultural, national or political from a party point of view, because there is a growing fear in Singapore that the radio is being used not for the State but for the Party in power.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member is fully aware that when additional sums are required to be spent under this Head and it is not possible to find a saving within that Head - and, in this instance, the expenditure is likely to be fairly substantial - Supplementary Estimates will be submitted to this Assembly. The Member for Farrer Park is fully aware of that.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 47 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 37.

    Sub-head 37 reads "Salaries of Radio Orchestra", and the current vote is $166,800. The Minister intends to run this orchestra in the next year for $75,000.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there are orchestras and orchestras. You could have an orchestra of three, five or eight, or you could have an orchestra of more. You could also have a symphony orchestra. Each of these orchestras costs different amounts, depending on the number of persons in the orchestra. But when an institution such as Radio Singapore has an orchestra, I take it that it must be an orchestra which comes very near - but not quite - to the symphony class which could render pieces in various ranges of music. The vote is being reduced by more than half the present vote. Judging from that, it would appear that the number in the orchestra

Column: 499

is going to be reduced by more than half. So the question arises: is that orchestra on reduced personnel worth maintaining?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Sir, I am glad to know that the Member for Farrer Park is as bad as myself in reading the Estimates! But if he will look at them, he will see an entry of $75,000 for 1961 as against a provision of $166,800 for 1960. That can give a wrong picture of what is happening in Radio Singapore.

    The current sum of $166,800 covers not only the salaries of members of the radio orchestra but also the fees paid to augmentees who are employed from time to time to complete the instruments required for certain types of music to be played by the Radio Orchestra, it also covers fees paid for music arrangements and orchestrations. The splitting of the sum of $166,800 into $75,000 for the salaries of the Radio Orchestra and $72,000 as fees for augmentees, arrangements and orchestrations which appear under sub-head 30 of the Estimates, is really a move to make the administration of this vote simpler and more clear-cut. There is no move to weaken the Radio Orchestra which has been built over the years, and I am very glad, Sir, to note that the Member for Farrer Park - at least in this instance - is so interested in culture as to listen to the Radio Orchestra, to express concern that his Sunday and Friday music might be of a lower tone as a result of reducing the number in the Orchestra. In fact, the Orchestra remains the same in number, but we just split the amount to help disburse the funds more efficiently.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am obliged to the Minister for Culture. If he will bear with me patiently as the evening progresses, he will know for certain how interested I am in culture, particularly his Ministry. May I have leave to withdraw?
